bcl:text.#text:
means the person in charge of the
          correctional centre and includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
a staff member designated by the person in charge of the correctional centre to
            exercise the powers and perform the duties and functions under section 12,
              13,
              14,
              15, 16, 18, 19, 19.1 or
              20, and

a member of a class of persons designated by the person in charge of the
            correctional centre to exercise the powers and perform the duties and functions under
              section
              12, 13, 14, 15, 16,
              18, 19, 19.1 or 20;

bcl:text.#text: means any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an intoxicant;
an explosive or bomb, or any component of an explosive or bomb;
if possessed without prior authorization, any currency;

if possessed without prior authorization, tobacco leaves or any products
            produced from tobacco in any form or for any use;

bcl:text.#text:
means a lawful place of confinement in
          British Columbia, including, without limitation, a jail, prison, lockup, place of
          imprisonment, camp or correctional institution, and any land connected with it, but does
          not include, except for the purposes of section 32 respecting shared
          facilities, any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prisons or lockups operated by police forces or police departments;

bcl:text.#text:
prisons or lockups operated by designated policing units, as defined in
              section
              1 of the , or by designated law
            enforcement units, as defined in section 1 of the ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: penitentiaries under the control of Canada;

bcl:text.#text: a youth custody centre as defined in the ;

includes the Court of Appeal, Supreme Court, Provincial
          Court and a justice of the peace;

means the Director of the Investigation and
          Standards Office;

means communication made or intended to
          be made by oral, written, electronic or prescribed means between an inmate and another
          person, including another inmate, other than a privileged communication specified under
            section 33 (2)
            (u);

means a person holding an appointment under
          section 2 (1) (a) or (b) and employed in a correctional centre and includes a person
          providing a service in a correctional centre under a contract with the
          minister;

means a program established under section
          23.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
This Act comes into force by regulation of the Lieutenant Governor in
          Council.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Probation officers and other officers and employees

bcl:text.#text: The minister may appoint under the

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
persons, or persons within a class of persons, to be probation officers,
              and

other officers and employees the minister considers necessary to exercise
              powers and perform duties under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In an appointment under subsection (1), the minister may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
limit the powers and duties that a person, officer or employee may exercise
              under this Act, and
make the appointment subject to terms and conditions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Persons, officers and employees appointed to exercise powers and perform duties
            under this Act are peace officers while exercising those powers and performing those
            duties.

Subsection (3) does not apply to the director or an employee of the
            Investigation and Standards Office.

bcl:text.#text:
Despite the , the minister may
            appoint persons required for the purposes of this Act to meet an actual or impending
            emergency.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
On request by a court and with the approval of the minister, a person may
            exercise the powers and perform the duties of a probation officer without remuneration
            for the purposes and in the geographic area of British Columbia specified in the
            approval.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Powers and duties of probation officers

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Subject to any limitations, terms and conditions imposed on the appointment
            under section 2
              (2), a probation officer

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is a probation officer for all of British Columbia,
is an officer of every court in British Columbia,
must prepare reports for the court as the court may order,

has power to procure and report information for the court in respect of a
              person convicted by the courts,

bcl:text.#text:
is, if appointed a parole supervisor under the  (Canada), a peace officer under the jurisdiction of
              the government,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: [Repealed 2007-8-10.]

is, if attached to the staff of a correctional centre, subject to the
              directions of the person in charge of the correctional centre, and must assist in
              casework services and post-release planning for inmates, and
has the additional prescribed powers and duties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A probation officer is responsible for the supervision of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: persons placed on probation by a court, and
persons subject to conditional sentences imposed by a court.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A probation officer charged with the supervision of a person on whom the passing
            of sentence was suspended, or who is subject to a probation order or a conditional
            sentence, may report to the court or prosecutor if the person fails to carry out the
            terms

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on which the passing of sentence was suspended,
of the probation order, or
of the conditional sentence.

bcl:text:
No action for damages lies or may be brought against a person holding an
            appointment under section 2 (1) (a) or (b) because of anything done or
            omitted
unless the thing was done or omitted in bad faith.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
in the performance or intended performance of a duty under this Act,
              or
in the exercise or intended exercise of a power under this Act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Subsection (1) does not absolve the government from vicarious liability
            for an act or omission for which it would be vicariously liable if this section were not
            in force.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
In recognition of the contribution to public safety that is made by staff members,
          the minister may issue medals for long service.

The Lieutenant Governor in Council may establish or discontinue correctional
            centres as the Lieutenant Governor in Council considers necessary.

A street, highway or place, public or private, along or across which an inmate
            may pass in going to or returning from work, duty or other absence authorized under
            section 21 or 22, and every place where an inmate may be under those sections, must,
            while so used by an inmate, be considered a portion of a correctional centre for the
            purposes of this Act, except for the purposes of section 17 (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The person in charge of a correctional centre is not required to accept a
              person into custody under a warrant of committal unless a certificate of a medical
              practitioner or nurse practitioner certifies for that person all of the
              following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the state of health of the person;
that the person is fit for transfer;

that the person is free from any infectious or contagious
                disease.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A person sentenced to imprisonment in, or ordered by competent authority to be
              conveyed to, a correctional centre from any other jail, prison or lockup may remain
              and be kept in lawful custody in the jail, prison or lockup from which the person was
              sentenced or ordered to be conveyed, until the certificate of health required by this
              section has been provided.

Subject to subsection (2), each correctional centre may receive
              inmates from any part of British Columbia.

The Lieutenant Governor in Council may, by order, designate a correctional
              centre as a regional correctional centre to receive inmates or classes of inmates from
              an area of British Columbia designated in the order.

Despite any order made under this section and the terms of any custodial
              disposition to the contrary, the person in charge of a correctional centre may direct
              that prisoners confined in one correctional centre be moved to another correctional
              centre.

On behalf of the government, the minister may enter into an agreement with a
              municipality for the detention in a correctional centre of persons whose detention is
              chargeable to the municipality on terms for reimbursement of expenses as may be
              mutually agreeable.

An agreement similar to that authorized under subsection (1) may be made for
              reimbursing municipalities for the expenses of detention in a municipal lockup of
              persons from inside or outside the municipality whose detention is chargeable to the
              government.

All persons lawfully acting under an agreement referred to in subsection
                (1) or (2) have full authority to detain persons and are
              empowered to do so.

Lockups and other institutions used for the purpose of an agreement made under
              this section are places of detention for the purposes and localities specified in the
              agreement.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Use of force and restraining devices

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Officers and employees appointed under this Act may use a reasonable degree
              and means of force for any of the following purposes:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to prevent injury or death to a person;
to prevent property damage;
to prevent an inmate from escaping;
to maintain custody and control of an inmate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A device used to physically restrain an inmate may only be used in prescribed
              circumstances and in accordance with prescribed procedures.

On admission, entry or return of an inmate to a correctional centre, an
              authorized person must conduct a search of the inmate and any personal possessions,
              including clothing, that the inmate may be carrying or wearing.

For the purpose of detecting contraband, an authorized person may without
              individualized suspicion conduct periodic searches of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
an inmate and any personal possessions, including clothing, that the inmate
                may be carrying or wearing, and
the inmate's cell and its contents.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If an authorized person believes on reasonable grounds that an inmate may be
              in possession of contraband or evidence relating to an offence under section 17
                (1), the authorized person may conduct a search of any of the following,
              as necessary in the circumstances:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the inmate and any personal possessions, including clothing, that the inmate
                may be carrying or wearing;
the inmate's cell and its contents.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A search under subsection (1), (2) or (3) may
              include a strip search conducted in accordance with the regulations.

A strip search of an inmate must be conducted by an authorized person of the
              same sex as the inmate unless the delay that would be caused by complying with this
              requirement would result in danger to human life or safety.

Subject to subsection (2), an authorized person may, for
              security or safety purposes and without individualized suspicion, conduct routine
              searches of a visitor entering or leaving or in the correctional centre and of any
              personal possessions, including clothing, that the visitors may be carrying or
              wearing.

If a visitor refuses to undergo a search under subsection (1), the authorized
              person may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
prohibit a contact visit with an inmate and authorize a non-contact visit,
                or
request the visitor to leave the correctional centre immediately.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A visitor must comply with a request made under subsection (2) (b).

If an authorized person believes on reasonable grounds that a visitor is
              carrying contraband or is in possession of evidence relating to an offence under
                section 17
                (1),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the authorized person may, with the visitor's consent, conduct a search of
                the visitor and any personal possessions, including clothing, that the visitor may
                be wearing or carrying, in order to find the contraband or evidence, or

the person in charge of the correctional centre may authorize the detention
                of the visitor in order to obtain the services of the police.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
With the visitor's consent, a search under subsection (4) (a) may include
              a strip search conducted in accordance with the regulations.

A strip search of a visitor must be conducted by an authorized person of the
              same sex as the visitor unless the delay that would be caused by complying with this
              requirement would result in danger to human life or safety.

If contraband or evidence relating to an offence under section 17
                (1) is found in a search under subsection (1) or (4) (a) of this section,
              the person in charge of the correctional centre may authorize the further detention of
              the visitor in order to obtain the services of the police.
A person detained under this section must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
be informed promptly of the reasons for the detention and of the person's
                right to retain and instruct counsel, and
be given a reasonable opportunity to retain and instruct counsel.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Search and detention of staff members

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An authorized person may without individualized suspicion conduct

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
routine searches, authorized for security or safety purposes by the person
                in charge of the correctional centre, of staff members entering or leaving or in the
                correctional centre and of any personal possessions, including clothing, that staff
                members may be carrying or wearing, and

random searches, authorized for security or safety purposes by the person in
                charge of the correctional centre of staff members' lockers.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A staff member must not impede or obstruct an authorized person conducting a
              search under subsection (1).

If an authorized person believes on reasonable grounds that a staff member is
              carrying contraband or is in possession of evidence relating to an offence under
                section 17
                (1),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the authorized person may, with the staff member's consent, conduct a search
                of the staff member, the staff member's locker in the correctional centre and any
                personal possessions, including clothing, that the staff member may be wearing or
                carrying, in order to find the contraband or evidence, or

the person in charge of the correctional centre may authorize the detention
                of the staff member in order to obtain the services of the police.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
With the staff member's consent, a search under subsection (3) (a) may include
              a strip search conducted in accordance with the regulations.

A strip search of a staff member must be conducted by an authorized person of
              the same sex as the staff member unless the delay that would be caused by complying
              with this requirement would result in danger to human life or safety.

If contraband or evidence relating to an offence under section 17
                (1) is found in a search under subsection (1) or (3) (a) of this section,
              the person in charge of the correctional centre may authorize the further detention of
              the staff member in order to obtain the services of the police.
A staff member detained under this section must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
be informed promptly of the reasons for the detention and of the staff member's
                right to retain and instruct counsel, and
be given a reasonable opportunity to retain and instruct counsel.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
An authorized person may without individualized suspicion conduct routine
              visual inspections or searches of vehicles that are on the property of a correctional
              centre.

If an authorized person believes on reasonable grounds that a vehicle
              entering, leaving or on the property of a correctional centre has been used, is about
              to be used or is being used in the commission of an offence under section 17
                (1), the authorized person may conduct a search of the vehicle and its
              contents in accordance with the regulations.

A person commits an offence if at a correctional centre the person possesses,
              delivers or sends to or receives from an inmate anything that is referred to in
              paragraph (a), (b) or (c) of the definition of "contraband" in section
              1.

A person commits an offence if the person trespasses on the grounds, buildings
              or other premises belonging or related to a correctional centre.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Powers of seizure and disposition of things seized

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A staff member may seize an object or substance if the staff member believes
              on reasonable grounds that the object or substance is contraband or evidence relating
              to an offence under section 17 (1).

As soon as practicable after an object or a substance is seized under
                subsection
                (1), the staff member must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
make a record describing the object or substance and the circumstances in
                which it was seized, and

deposit the object or substance in a secure place at the correctional
                centre.

bcl:text.#text:
Section 23
                (4) of the  applies if an object or
              substance seized under subsection (1) is required as evidence in a trial, inquiry or
              proceeding other than a hearing referred to in section 33 (2) (n) of this
              Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The person in charge of the correctional centre must return an object or
              substance seized under subsection (1) to its owner if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
it is in the custody or control of the person in charge of the correctional
                centre,

it is not contraband or evidence relating to an offence under section 17
                  (1), and
there is no dispute about who owns it.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If an object or substance is seized from an inmate under subsection
                (1) and the object or substance is contraband but its possession outside
              the correctional centre would be lawful, the person in charge of the correctional
              centre may direct that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the object or substance be kept in a secure place at the correctional centre
                and returned to the inmate on the inmate's release from custody,

the inmate be given 30 days to make arrangements for the disposal or
                safekeeping of the object or substance outside the correctional centre,
                or
the object or substance be disposed of if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: it is of a perishable nature and subject to spoilage,
it will deteriorate in value if kept,
its custody involves unreasonable expense or inconvenience,
keeping it is unsafe, or
it is dangerous to life, health or property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
An object or substance seized under subsection (1) is forfeited to
              the government in accordance with the regulations if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
within 30 days after being notified of its seizure, the owner does not
                request its return,

the owner cannot be located and 3 months have passed since the
                seizure,

the object or substance is determined to be contraband in a hearing referred
                to in section 33 (2) (n) and possession of it outside the correctional
                centre would be unlawful, or
in the case of an owner who is an inmate,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text:
possession of it by the inmate would constitute possession of contraband,
                  and

the inmate has not arranged for the disposal or safekeeping of the object
                  or substance outside the correctional centre within 30 days after being given the
                  opportunity to do so in accordance with subsection (5)
                  (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
An authorized person may restrict, intercept, monitor or record inmate
              communication in accordance with this section and the regulations.

An authorized person may without individualized suspicion intercept or record
              inmate communication.

An authorized person may restrict, intercept or monitor inmate communication
              if one or more of the following apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the authorized person has reasonable grounds to believe that the inmate
                is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: involved in illegal activities,
harassing or causing harm to others, or

participating in an activity that may jeopardize the safety, security or
                  operation of the correctional centre;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
a court order restricts or prohibits communication or contact between the
                inmate and the other person;

the other person has indicated to the authorized person that the other person does
                not wish to communicate with the inmate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If inmate communication has been restricted, an authorized person must as soon
              as practicable inform the inmate in writing and give the reasons under subsection
                (3) for the restriction.
An authorized person may,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
in prescribed circumstances or in relation to prescribed classes of inmate
                communication, disclose in the prescribed manner that a communication is inmate
                communication, and

in prescribed circumstances or in relation to prescribed classes of
                communication specified under section 33 (2) (u) as privileged, disclose in the
                prescribed manner that a privileged communication originates from the correctional
                centre.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
For the purposes of subsection (1) (b), an authorized person may without
              individualized suspicion intercept a privileged communication.
An authorized person may demand that an inmate submit to urinalysis

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
at any time, if the authorized person believes on reasonable grounds that
                the inmate has taken an intoxicant into the inmate's body, or

if abstention from an intoxicant is a condition of a temporary absence, work
                program, voluntary treatment program or conditional release and urinalysis is
                required to monitor an inmate's compliance with the condition,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at regular intervals, or

at any time, if the authorized person believes on reasonable grounds that
                  the inmate has breached the condition.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An authorized person who makes a demand under this section must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
first inform the inmate of the basis of the demand and the consequences of
                failure to comply with the demand, and

carry out the demand and take the sample in accordance with the
                regulations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The minister may authorize the employment or attendance of an inmate for any
              specific work, duty or purpose beyond the limits of a correctional centre.

The degree of supervision of the inmate must be determined by the person in
              charge of the correctional centre.

During the employment or attendance referred to in subsection
                (1), the inmate is subject to the rules, regulations and discipline of
              the correctional centre, as applicable, and must obey all instructions given to the inmate by the person in charge of the correctional centre.

The minister may authorize an inmate to be absent from a correctional centre
              with or without escort, subject to any conditions that the minister considers
              appropriate, if in the minister's opinion the absence is necessary or
              desirable

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for medical, educational or humanitarian reasons, or

to assist in the inmate's rehabilitation or reintegration into the
                community.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A temporary absence under this section may be authorized for a maximum period
              of 60 days and may be renewed by the minister for one or more periods of a maximum of
              60 days on reassessment of the case.

Despite subsection (2), a temporary absence for medical
              reasons may be authorized for an unlimited period.
[Repealed 2007-8-11.]

During the period of a temporary absence authorized under subsection
                (1), the inmate is subject to the rules, regulations and discipline of
              the correctional centre, as applicable, and must obey all instructions given to the inmate by the person in charge of the correctional centre.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote:
Suspension, cancellation and revocation of temporary
            absence

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The minister may suspend, cancel or revoke an inmate's temporary absence under
                section
                22, before or after it begins, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
a breach of a condition of the absence has occurred or, in the minister's
                opinion, the suspension, cancellation or revocation is necessary to prevent a breach
                of a condition of the absence,

the grounds for authorizing the absence have changed or no longer exist,
                or

based on information that could not reasonably have been provided at the
                time the absence was authorized, the application has been reassessed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If the minister suspends, cancels or revokes an inmate's temporary absence,
              the minister may issue a warrant or notice of suspension, cancellation or revocation
              for the apprehension and recommittal of the inmate.

A peace officer may arrest a person without a warrant or notice and remand the
              person into custody if the peace officer believes on reasonable grounds that a warrant
              or notice

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
has been issued under subsection (2) in respect of that person,
                and
is still in force.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Unless the warrant or notice is produced within 48 hours after an arrest is
              made under subsection (3), the inmate must be released.
The minister may establish and administer work programs.

bcl:text.#text:
The , the
                 and the  do not apply to
              inmates in respect of or due to their participation in a work program.

In this section,  means the Corrections Work
              Program Account continued under subsection (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The Corrections Work Program Account is continued as a special account in the
              general fund of the consolidated revenue fund.

Money in the account must be managed and accounted for in accordance with any
              directives that Treasury Board may issue from time to time and may, without an
              appropriation other than this section, be spent for work programs.
There must be credited to the account

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
money authorized by the Treasury Board for the purposes of the account,
                and

subject to the directives of Treasury Board, all money received by the
                government from operation of the work programs or by way of return on money expended
                from the account.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If the minister authorizes an inmate's absence from a correctional centre in
              order to be employed for wages, the minister may require that any wages earned by the
              inmate from this employment be applied in the manner set out in subsections
                (4) and (5).

If an inmate receives compensation as a result of the inmate's participation in
              a work program, the minister may require that the compensation received by the inmate
              be applied in the manner set out in subsections (4) and 
              (5).

bcl:text:
If an inmate is employed for wages outside of a correctional centre or is
              participating in a work program inside or outside of a correctional centre, the
              minister may require

to forward the total amount owed to the inmate, less deductions required by
              law, to the person in charge of the correctional centre.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the employer of the inmate, or
the person who is paying compensation to the inmate

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The person in charge of the correctional centre must, subject to the
              minister's approval, disburse the money received by the inmate for the following
              purposes in descending order of priority:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the maintenance and support of the inmate's dependants in sums the minister
                may direct;
the actual cost of travel expenses and meals for the inmate;
the cost of keeping the inmate at the correctional centre;

any other expense that the minister considers is in the best interest of the
                inmate or the dependants of the inmate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The person in charge of the correctional centre must credit any balance
              remaining to the account of the inmate to be paid to the inmate on the inmate's release
              from custody.

Despite subsections (4) and (5), the person in charge of
              the correctional centre may waive or vary the manner of disbursing the earnings of the
              inmate received by the person in charge in any way that the person in charge, in the person's discretion, considers necessary for the benefit of the inmate or the dependants
              of the inmate.

The person in charge of the correctional centre receiving money under this
              section must keep proper records of its receipt and disbursement and account to the
              inmate on the inmate's release from custody.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
An inmate who is serving a sentence for civil contempt or for an offence under
            an enactment may be credited with earned remission in accordance with the
            regulations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The minister must provide for the inspection of each correctional centre on a
              periodic basis that the minister considers appropriate in the
              circumstances.

The minister or a person conducting an inspection under this section may at
              any time

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: enter a correctional centre, and
access any part of the correctional centre.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The minister or person conducting the inspection may examine any thing or any
              record, except a medical record of an inmate, in the correctional centre.
The minister must maintain the Investigation and Standards Office.
The director

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
may delegate in writing one or more of the director's powers and duties to
                an employee of the Investigation and Standards Office,

must investigate a matter respecting the administration of this Act on the
                written request of the minister,

may investigate a matter respecting the administration of this Act on the
                director's own motion,

must, subject to subsection (3), investigate complaints about the
                administration of this Act as it affects the complainant, on receiving a written
                complaint from

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an inmate,
a person on probation under this Act, or
a person who is subject to a conditional sentence,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
must report the director's findings under paragraph (b), (c)
                  or 
                  (d) in writing to the minister, and
[Repealed 2007-9-68.]
is entitled to access at any time to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a correctional centre and an inmate,

a person appointed or approved under section 2 or 3 or a
                  staff member, and

a file or document under the custody and control of the
                  ministry.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The director may refuse to investigate a complaint or may stop or postpone
              investigation of a complaint if the director considers that the complaint is
              frivolous, vexatious or trivial or is not made in good faith.

An employee to whom a power or duty is delegated under subsection (2)
                (a) may not delegate that power or duty to another person.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote:
Power to compel persons to answer questions and order
            disclosure

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
For the purposes of an investigation under section 28 (2) (b), (c) or (d), the
              director may make an order requiring a person to do either or both of the
              following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
attend, in person or by electronic means, before the director to answer
                questions on oath or affirmation, or in any other manner;

produce for the director a record or thing in the person's possession or
                control.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may apply to the Supreme Court for an order

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
directing a person to comply with an order made under subsection
                  (1), or

directing any directors and officers of a person to cause the person to
                comply with an order made under subsection (1).

bcl:section.bcl:text:
The failure or refusal of a person subject to an order under section 28.1
            to do any of the following makes the person, on application to the Supreme Court by the
            director, liable to be committed for contempt as if in breach of an order or judgment of
            the Supreme Court:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: attend before the director;
take an oath or make an affirmation;
answer questions;
produce records or things in the person's possession or control.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Subject to subsection (2), no legal proceeding for damages lies
              or may be commenced or maintained against the director, or a person acting on behalf
              of or under the direction of the director, because of anything done or
              omitted

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
in the performance or intended performance of any duty under section
                  28, or

in the exercise or intended exercise of any power under sections 28 to
                  28.2.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Subsection (1) does not apply to a person referred to in that subsection
              in relation to anything done or omitted by that person in bad faith.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Offence of obstructing inspections or investigations

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A person must not obstruct or impede or refuse to admit the minister or a
              person conducting an inspection under section 27 or a person
              conducting an investigation under section 28.

A person must not aid or assist a person in obstructing or impeding or
              refusing to admit the minister or a person conducting an inspection under section 27
              or a person conducting an investigation under section 28.

A person who contravenes subsection (1) or (2) commits an
              offence.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
If an inmate whose absence from a correctional centre is authorized under
              section
              21 or 22 fails to return to the correctional centre when
            instructed to do so, the inmate is deemed to be at large without lawful excuse and may
            be apprehended, with or without a warrant, by a peace officer and returned to
            custody.

bcl:text.#text:
Section
            5 of the  does not apply to this
          Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Jurisdiction of the National Parole Board

bcl:text.#text:
The National Parole Board is authorized to exercise in British Columbia the
          jurisdiction described in section 108 (2) of the  (Canada).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:text.#text:
means a person who is detained in custody
            but has not been remanded or committed to custody by a court;

means a correctional centre that also
            contains facilities for the detention of police prisoners.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
On behalf of the government, the minister may enter into an agreement with the
            City of Vancouver

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
respecting the establishment, building, management, operation and security of
              a shared facility in the City of Vancouver,

respecting the provision of detention, security and ancillary services for the
              shared facility, and

for reimbursement of expenses incurred by the government or the City of
              Vancouver in relation to those matters under paragraphs (a) and 
              (b).

bcl:text.#text:
The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations referred to in section 41 of the
              .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may
            make regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
for the management, operation, and security of correctional
              centres;

establishing a process for receiving and responding to inmate
              complaints;
respecting the separate confinement or segregation of inmates;

respecting the use of force and physical restraint devices on
              inmates;

respecting searches under sections 13 to 16,
              including, without limitation, strip searches;

specifying the manner in which a demand that an inmate submit to urinalysis be
              carried out and a urine sample be taken;

governing visits to inmates in correctional centres and the conduct of
              visitors while in a correctional centre;
respecting the disposal of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text:
unclaimed property abandoned by an inmate at a correctional centre,
                including, without limitation, providing for the forfeiture of the property to the
                government, and
property forfeited under section 18 (6);

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
for the diet, clothing, maintenance, accommodation, employment and training of
              inmates;

establishing rules governing the conduct of inmates in a correctional
              centre;

establishing and providing for an informal resolution process that may be
              employed in relation to breaches of rules referred to in paragraph (k);

respecting hearings in relation to an alleged breach of the rules referred to
              in paragraph
                (k), including, without limitation, the practices and procedures for the
              hearings;

establishing and providing for a range of penalties for breaches of rules
              referred to in paragraph (k) and specifying criteria to be applied
              by a person presiding over a disciplinary hearing in imposing a penalty from the range
              of penalties established;

bcl:text.#text:
prescribing allowances for persons who preside over disciplinary hearings who
              are not employees under the ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
establishing a process for review of a decision made in a disciplinary
              hearing, and the powers and duties of a person conducting the review;

respecting the restriction, interception, monitoring or recording of inmate
              communication;

providing for the handling, retention and disposal of inmate communication
              that is intercepted or recorded;

specifying communications between an inmate and another person that are
              privileged;

governing inmates who are authorized to be absent from a correctional
              centre;
respecting the inspection of correctional centres;
defining words or expressions used but not defined in this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The minister must post, in legible characters and in conspicuous parts of a
            correctional centre, copies of regulations made under subsection (2) that relate to
            the treatment, conduct and discipline of inmates.

bcl:text.#text:
Despite the  or any other Act,
            the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
prescribing the compulsory retirement age for a person holding an appointment
              under section 2 (1) (a) or (b) and employed in a correctional centre;

specifying the qualifications that are necessary to be exempted from a
              regulation under paragraph (a) and tests that measure the ability of
              a person holding an appointment to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: exercise the powers and duties of the appointment, and

contribute to the maintenance of safety and security and the management and
                operation of a correctional centre.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Regulations made under subsection (2) (k) may be different for different
            correctional centres.
A regulation under subsection (4) may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be made applicable generally or to a specific class of persons,
for the purposes of the regulation, define classes of persons, and
provide differently for different classes of persons.
